title: R45345
content: Whistleblowing in the Intelligence Community (IC) involves reporting violations of law, mismanagement, waste of resources, abuse of authority, or threats to public health and safety. Protection for IC whistleblowers is focused on safeguarding classified information. Whistleblowing is seen as a way to save taxpayer money, promote ethical work environments, and prompt corrective actions. Whistleblower protections in the Intelligence Community (IC) are extended to those who make lawful disclosures to safeguard classified information. Protections do not cover unauthorized disclosures, differences in policy or analysis, or adverse personnel decisions if legality or constitutionality is not a concern. The whistleblower protections in the Intelligence Community do not cover differences in policy or analysis unless there is a concern over legality or constitutionality. Protections also do not apply to adverse personnel decisions if the agency can show it would have taken the same action without the disclosure. The Director of National Intelligence has established procedures for protected disclosures and provides guidance on whistleblower process and protections for IC contractors, Armed Forces members, and federal employees. There are concerns about transparency in internal processes and adequacy of protections for IC contractors. The IAA for FY2010 included the first general provisions for protection of whistleblowers as part of legislation that established the Office of the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community (OIGIC), headed by the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community (IGIC). Section 405(a)(1) of the IAA for FY2010 added a new Section 103H to the National Security Act of 1947, permitting lawful disclosures to the IGIC. Section 405(a)(1) of the IAA for FY2010 added a new Section 103H to the National Security Act of 1947, allowing lawful disclosures to the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community (IGIC) regarding violations of laws, rules, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or threats to public health and safety. The IGIC is authorized to receive and investigate complaints or information from any person within the intelligence community, with provisions to protect the identity of the whistleblower unless deemed necessary by the IGIC. Section 405 of the IAA for FY2010 allows lawful disclosures to the Inspector General of the Intelligence Community regarding violations of laws, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or threats to public health and safety. The Inspector General must protect the whistleblower's identity unless disclosure is unavoidable during the investigation. No reprisal can be taken against the whistleblower unless the complaint was knowingly false. Protections against reprisals for lawful disclosures were clarified by the IAA for FY2010 and PPD-19 signed by President Obama in 2012. PPD-19 specifically protects IC employees with access to classified information. PPD-19, signed by President Obama in 2012, provides protections for intelligence community whistleblowers with access to classified information. It defines protected disclosures as information disclosed to specific officials that the employee reasonably believes to be lawful. PPD-19 protects intelligence community whistleblowers who disclose violations of laws or regulations, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or dangers to public health or safety. It prohibits reprisals that could impact access to classified information or involve personnel actions against the whistleblower. IC elements must have a process for employees to challenge retaliatory personnel actions. PPD-19 prohibits reprisals that could affect a whistleblower's access to classified information or involve personnel actions against them. IC elements must certify a process for employees to challenge retaliatory actions, with the Inspector General determining if a violation occurred and making recommendations for corrective action. The agency head is required to consider the IG's findings and recommendations, although they are not obligated to accept them. The agency head must consider the Inspector General's findings and recommendations regarding reprisals for lawful disclosures. IC agencies need to certify a review process for employees to appeal actions involving access to classified information. Whistleblowers can request an external review by an IG panel if the agency review process is exhausted. The agency is not required to accept the panel's recommendations for corrective action. PPD-19 allows whistleblowers to request an external review by an IG panel chaired by the IGIC if agency review process is exhausted. The panel's decision may prompt agency consideration of corrective action. IGIC reports annually to congressional intelligence committees on determinations and recommendations. Training on whistleblower protections is mandated for employees with classified information access. Section 601 of Title VI protects whistleblowers from retaliation for lawful disclosures to specified entities. Title VI of the FY2014 IAA provides statutory protections for IC whistleblowers against reprisals, including safeguards for lawful disclosures to designated entities. The legislation defines lawful disclosure as revealing violations of federal laws or regulations, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or threats to public health and safety. Additionally, Section 602 of Title VI prohibits retaliatory actions, such as revoking security clearances, against covered government employee whistleblowers. Section 602 of Title VI of the FY2014 IAA provides protections for government employee whistleblowers who make lawful disclosures, including safeguards against retaliatory revocation of security clearances. The provision also requires the development of appeal policies for whistleblower cases, with no mention of contractors. The whistleblower can retain their employment status pending the appeal outcome, but there is no provision for judicial review or a private right of action. The amendment to the Federal Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978, known as P.L. 115-118, provides protections for IC contractor whistleblowers, allowing them to make lawful disclosures to designated individuals or agencies, similar to protections for IC employees under Title VI of the IAA for FY2014. Section 110 of the Federal Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 (P.L. 115-118) provides clear protections for IC contractors who make lawful complaints against retaliatory personnel actions.
